subject: RE: [junit] Re: Having trouble getting new junit install to work in mac osx panther
msgSnippet: HOME is one of the environment variables you get for free with Unix. Start up a shell and type: echo $HOME and you ll see something meaningful. For example,
messageBody:
HOME is one of the environment variables you get for "free" with Unix. Start up a shell and type:

echo $HOME

and you'll see something meaningful. For example, my short userid on my mac is "simon", so when I type the above command I get:

/Users/simon

Simon

>-----Original Message-----
>From: Lido [mailto:lido@...]
>Sent: Monday, January 19, 2004 11:28 AM
>To: junit@yahoogroups.com
>Subject: [junit] Re: Having trouble getting new junit install
>to work in
>mac osx panther
>
>
>Where would $HOME be on OSX? Do you just mean my home
>directory? There is no
>.bashrc file in there. There was no .tcshrc file in there
>until I created it and if I use the
>source command to run what's in that file, the next time I run
>my terminal program
>the settings in that file are not working again and I have to
>source the file again.
>
>--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, Jim Dixon <jdd@d...> wrote:
>> On Mon, 19 Jan 2004, Demyanovich, Craig - Apogent wrote:
>>
>> > If you're using bash as your shell, you'll want to use
>'export' instead of
>> > 'setenv'. Furthermore, place the export command in a file
>named '.bachrc'
>>
>> That's a typo. The export command should be in
>> $HOME/.bashrc
>> *
>>
>> --
